title: November 17
description:
Milo's class went a 3 day trip to Coloma, a little town on the Sacramento River where the California Gold Rush started in 1848. Milo loved it. Lucie went as a chaperone and also had a great time. Here are some extra photos from Coloma.

In other news, San Francisco was transformed into Gotham city for a day to satisfy the wish of a 5-year-old cancer victim. He had asked the Make-A-Wish Foundation if he could become Batman. There was on outpouring of support: thousands of people volunteered to help make his wish a reality.

That morning, with the batkid story on the radio, Lucie explained the Make-a-Wish foundation to the kids:

Milo
Is it for adults too?! They could have taken grand-p√®re to Disney World or something before he died!
Lucie
No, it's just for kids [mind churning to come up with an explanation]
Felix
I know why. Adults have had a chance to accumulate lots of happy memories. But kids have had a shorter life, they need the help.

children.title: Coloma
children.description:
Milo's 4th grade class on their three day trip to Gold Rush territory.

They stayed at CODS (Coloma Outdoor Discovery School). It's a great program. Not only did the kids learn about the Gold Rush and visit famous historical landmarks such as Sutter's Mill, they also got to pretend to be gold miners.

children.title: Chaperone
children.description:
Lucie was a chaperone. She had a blast. Just like the kids, her favorite activity was panning for gold.

CODS loaded 4 large troughs with water, gravel and tiny flakes of gold. You get to keep all the gold you find.

children.title: Panning
children.description:
By the end of the trip, Lucie had perfected her technique and could find specks of gold at the bottom of her pan after almost every try.

She made it her mission to help the kids who hadn't had any luck. Everyone wants to go home with at least one small fleck of gold.

children.title: Gold
children.description:
Gold is very heavy. If you patiently wiggle your pan back and forth in the water with a gentle motion, the gravel eventually washes out and you're left with dark sand and whatever sinks to the bottom (such as gold) with a little luck.

The flecks of gold were very small. It took a sharp eye to spot them.

children.title: Jess
children.description:
Eureka! Jess found gold!

Each kid received a leather pouch and a small vial to store their loot.

children.title: Vial
children.description: Lucie and Milo shared a vial with the family gold.

children.title: Kitchen
children.description: During the communal meals, kids pulled shifts on kitchen duty. They help put dirty dishes away.

children.title: Catherine
children.description: Catherine, Sam's mom, was also a chaperone. She and Lucie shared a bunkhouse with 10 little girls.

children.title: Booklet
children.description: During the day we divided in groups of 12 students with 2 parent chaperones. Milo was not in Lucie's group. Still, their groups sometimes ran into each other during certain activities.

children.title: Hoedown
children.description: Milo, Jess and August wait for their turn to dance at the Hoedown.

children.title: Dance
children.description: Dance around! Dance around! Don't fall on the ground!

children.title: Rich Bar
children.description: Lucie was a parent chaperone for the trip to the trip to California gold country. One of her responsibilities: memorialize in photos the kids in her group.

children.title: Spar Wars
children.description: Back in the bay area, Felix competed in Spar Wars, our dojo's sparring competition.

children.title: 2nd Place
children.description: Nicky, Joshua and Felix won 2nd place in the Team Sparring competition.

children.title: D&amp;D
children.description:
Sunday afternoon D&D with the guys.

Bedtime Sunday night, Felix was mumbling to Dean about his fantastic weekend as he drifted off to sleep:

  • A Boy Scout charity food gathering event
  • Spar Wars at the dojo
  • A sleepover at Addison and Parker's house
  • Epic card battles of Magic: The Gathering in the morning
  • A crepe taste-off
  • D&D with the guys
  • A movie with Dean and Milo
He pondered that time should move slow when you're having fun, so the best times like this weekend don't pass in the blink of an eye.

children.title: Selfie
children.description: Milo created this digital self-portrait in computer class.

children.title: V-Day
children.description:
As we've mentioned before, Milo's been on a three year boycott of Nutella, ever since he found out that palm oil is mostly made by clear-cutting jungles to plant palm plantations, which destroys the orangutans' very limited habitat.

Milo's gotten his entire class to swear off Nutella for the last few years.

But now there's BIG NEWS. In a tremendous victory to socially conscious kids everywhere, Nutella has said they will only use zero-deforestation palm oil!!!!!!

This is the poster Milo took to school to declare the end of the boycott.

children.title: Celebration
children.description: Sam, Kyler, Marco and Milo are thrilled to hear that Nutella will no longer kill orangutans.

children.title: Heating the Sauces
children.description:
To celebrate, we engineered a taste test between Nutella crepes and ones made with our substitute chocolate spread of the last few years: Nocciolata.

Here we heat the chocolate sauces in a bowl of warm water, to bring them to a consistency amenable to smooth spreading.

children.title: Half Crepe
children.description: The first crepe:  one side Nutella, one side Nocciolata.

children.title: First Bite
children.description: Milo's first bite of Nutella in three years.

children.title: The Winner?
children.description:
The winner? It was very close, but we've gotten used to the taste of Nocciolata. And since they use NO palm oil, that's even better than orangutan-friendly palm oil.

So we're sticking to Nocciolata!
